title: Facilitates absentee voting in local jails and designates several agencies as assisting agencies for voter registration purposes
summary: Facilitates absentee voting in local correctional facilities and designates the division of probation, the department of correctional services, and the division of parole as assisting agencies for voter registration purposes.

       AN ACT to amend the correction law and the election law, in relation  to
         absentee  voting  by eligible inmates of local correctional facilities
         and designating certain  agencies  as  assisting  agencies  for  voter
         registration

         THE  PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section 1. The correction law is amended by adding a new  section  510
    2  to read as follows:
    3    S  510. ABSENTEE VOTING BY QUALIFIED INMATES. THE CHIEF ADMINISTRATIVE
    4  OFFICER OF THE LOCAL CORRECTIONAL FACILITY,  OR  HIS  OR  HER  DESIGNEE,
    5  SHALL  INFORM EACH INMATE AT SUCH FACILITY OF THEIR RIGHT TO REGISTER TO
    6  VOTE. IN ADDITION, SUCH NOTICE SHALL BE  POSTED  IN  A  PROMINENT  PLACE
    7  WHERE  INMATES  CONGREGATE  AND  PRINTED IN BLOCK LETTERS.   SUCH POSTED
    8  NOTICE SHALL INCLUDE QUALIFICATIONS REQUIRED TO EXERCISE  THE  RIGHT  TO
    9  VOTE,  AND  OF  THE  AVAILABILITY  AT THE LOCAL CORRECTIONAL FACILITY OF
   10  ASSISTANCE TO REGISTER TO VOTE, REQUEST AN ABSENTEE BALLOT  APPLICATION,
   11  AND  TO  VOTE VIA ABSENTEE BALLOT. SUCH CHIEF ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICER, OR
   12  HIS OR HER DESIGNEE, SHALL ASSIST  ANY  OTHERWISE  ELIGIBLE  INMATES  IN
   13  REGISTERING TO VOTE IN THE SAME MANNER AND EXTENT AS THE AGENCIES LISTED
   14  IN  SECTION  5-211  OF  THE  ELECTION LAW, ASSIST ANY OTHERWISE ELIGIBLE
   15  INMATES IN REQUESTING AN ABSENTEE BALLOT APPLICATION PURSUANT TO SECTION
   16  8-400 OF THE ELECTION LAW, AND ASSIST ANY OTHERWISE ELIGIBLE INMATES  IN
   17  VOTING BY ABSENTEE BALLOT PURSUANT TO SECTION 8-407 OF THE ELECTION LAW.
   18    S  2.  Section 8-406 of the election law, as amended by chapter 296 of
   19  the laws of 1988, is amended to read as follows:
   20    S 8-406. Absentee ballots, delivery of. If the board shall  find  that
   21  the  applicant  is a qualified voter of the election district containing
   22  his residence as stated in his  statement  and  that  his  statement  is
   23  sufficient,  it shall, as soon as practicable after it shall have deter-

    1  mined his right thereto, mail to him at an address designated by him, or
    2  deliver to him, or to any person designated for such purpose in  writing
    3  by  him,  at the office of the board, such an absentee voter's ballot or
    4  set of ballots and an envelope therefor. If the ballot or ballots are to
    5  be  sent  outside of the United States to a country other than Canada or
    6  Mexico, such ballot or ballots shall be sent by air mail. However, if an
    7  applicant who is eligible for an absentee ballot  is  a  resident  of  a
    8  facility  operated  or  licensed  by,  or under the jurisdiction of, the
    9  department of mental hygiene, or a resident of a facility defined  as  a
   10  nursing  home  or  residential health care facility pursuant to subdivi-
   11  sions two and three of section two thousand eight  hundred  one  of  the
   12  public  health  law, or a resident of a hospital or other facility oper-
   13  ated by the Veteran's Administration of the United States,  OR  A  LOCAL
   14  CORRECTIONAL  FACILITY  such  absentee  ballot  need not be so mailed or
   15  delivered to any such applicant but, may be delivered to  the  voter  in
   16  the  manner  prescribed by section 8-407 of this [chapter] TITLE if such
   17  facility is located in the county or city in which such voter is  eligi-
   18  ble to vote.
   19    S  3. The section heading and subdivisions 1 and 3 of section 8-407 of
   20  the election law, the section heading as added by  chapter  296  of  the
   21  laws  of  1988 and subdivisions 1 and 3 as amended by chapter 195 of the
   22  laws of 2001, are amended to read as follows:
   23    Voting by residents of nursing homes, residential health care  facili-
   24  ties, facilities operated or licensed, or under the jurisdiction of, the
   25  department  of mental hygiene or hospitals or facilities operated by the
   26  Veteran's Administration of the United States, OR A  LOCAL  CORRECTIONAL
   27  FACILITY.  1.  The board of elections of a county or city in which there
   28  is located at least one facility operated  or  licensed,  or  under  the
   29  jurisdiction of, the department of mental hygiene, or a facility defined
   30  as a nursing home or residential health care facility pursuant to subdi-
   31  visions  two  and three of section two thousand eight hundred one of the
   32  public health law or an adult care facility subject to the provisions of
   33  title two of article seven of the social services law, or a hospital  or
   34  other  facility  operated  by the Veteran's Administration of the United
   35  States, OR A LOCAL  CORRECTIONAL  FACILITY  AS  DEFINED  BY  SUBDIVISION
   36  SIXTEEN  OF  SECTION  TWO OF THE CORRECTION LAW shall provide that resi-
   37  dents of each such facility for which such board has  received  [twenty-
   38  five]  FIFTEEN or more applications for absentee ballots from voters who
   39  are eligible to vote by absentee ballot in such city or county  at  such
   40  election, may vote by absentee ballot only in the manner provided for in
   41  this section. Such board may, in its discretion, provide that the proce-
   42  dure  described  in  this  subdivision  shall  be applicable to all such
   43  facilities in such county or city without regard to the number of absen-
   44  tee ballot applications received from the residents of any such  facili-
   45  ty.
   46    3.  Not earlier than thirteen days before or later than the day before
   47  such an election such a board of inspectors shall, between the hours  of
   48  nine  o'clock  in the morning and five o'clock in the evening, attend at
   49  each such facility for the residents of which the board of elections has
   50  custody of [twenty-five] FIFTEEN or more absentee  ballots  or,  if  the
   51  board  of  elections  has  so provided, each such facility for which the
   52  board has custody of one or more such absentee ballots, pursuant to  the
   53  provisions of this chapter.
   54    S  4.  The  opening paragraph of section 5-211 of the election law, as
   55  amended by chapter 200 of the laws  of  1996,  is  amended  to  read  as
   56  follows:

       A. 1711                             3

    1    Each  agency designated as a participating agency under the provisions
    2  of this section shall implement and administer a program of distribution
    3  of voter registration forms pursuant to the provisions of this  section.
    4  The  following  offices  which  provide public assistance and/or provide
    5  state funded programs primarily engaged in providing services to persons
    6  with  disabilities are hereby designated as voter registration agencies:
    7  designated as the state agencies which provide public assistance are the
    8  department of [social services] FAMILY ASSISTANCE and the department  of
    9  health.   Also designated as public assistance agencies are all agencies
   10  of local government that provide such assistance.  Designated  as  state
   11  agencies  that  provide programs primarily engaged in providing services
   12  to people with disabilities are the department of labor, office for  the
   13  aging, division of veterans' affairs, office of mental health, office of
   14  vocational  and  educational services for individuals with disabilities,
   15  commission on quality of care for  the  mentally  disabled,  office  [of
   16  mental  retardation  and]  FOR  PEOPLE  WITH developmental disabilities,
   17  commission for the blind and visually handicapped, office of  alcoholism
   18  and  substance  abuse services, the office of the advocate for the disa-
   19  bled and all offices which administer programs established or funded  by
   20  such  agencies.  Additional state agencies designated as voter registra-
   21  tion offices are the department of state [and], the division of workers'
   22  compensation, THE DIVISION OF PROBATION AND  CORRECTIONAL  ALTERNATIVES,
   23  THE DEPARTMENT OF CORRECTIONAL SERVICES AND THE DIVISION OF PAROLE. Such
   24  agencies  shall be required to offer voter registration forms to persons
   25  upon initial application for services, renewal  or  recertification  for
   26  services  and change of address relating to such services. Such agencies
   27  shall also be responsible for  providing  assistance  to  applicants  in
   28  completing  voter  registration  forms,  receiving  and transmitting the
   29  completed application form from all applicants who  wish  to  have  such
   30  form  transmitted to the appropriate board of elections. The state board
   31  of elections shall, together with representatives of the  department  of
   32  defense,  develop  and  implement  procedures  for including recruitment
   33  offices of the armed forces of the United States as  voter  registration
   34  offices  when  such offices are so designated by federal law.  The state
   35  board shall also make request  of  the  United  States  Immigration  and
   36  Naturalization  Service to include applications for registration by mail
   37  with any materials which are given to new citizens.  All institutions of
   38  the state university of New York and the city university  of  New  York,
   39  shall,  at  the  beginning of the school year, and again in January of a
   40  year in which the president of the  United  States  is  to  be  elected,
   41  provide  an  application  for  registration to each student in each such
   42  institution.  The state board of elections may, by regulation,  grant  a
   43  waiver from any or all of the requirements of this section to any office
   44  or  program  of  an agency, if it determines that it is not feasible for
   45  such office or program to administer such requirement.
   46    S 5. This act shall take effect on the one hundred eightieth day after
   47  it shall have become a law, provided, however that effective  immediate-
   48  ly,  the  addition,  amendment and/or repeal of any rules or regulations
   49  necessary for the implementation of this act on its  effective  date  is
   50  authorized  and  directed  to  be  made  and completed on or before such
   51  effective date.
